1.5 The theory-theory In response to such difficulties, many have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of

many have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded
any have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded.
ny have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. 
y have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. A
 have urged that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. Al

that a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. All the benefi
hat a better variant of functionalism is theory-theory (Lewis, 1966, 1970, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. All the benefit

According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. 70, 1980; Churchland, 1981; Stich, 1983). According to this view, mental state concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitm

te concepts (like theoretical concepts in science) get their life and sense from their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. What of the point

All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. What of the point

What of the point that some mental states can be conceptualised purely or primarily in terms 
rom their position in a substantive theory of the causal structure and functioning of the mind. And on this view, to know what a belief is (to grasp the concept of belief) is to know sufficiently much of the theory of mind within which that concept is embedded. All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. What of the point that some mental states can be conceptualised purely or primarily in terms of feel? (Compare the diagnostician who can recognise a cancer  immediately and without infere
 which that concept is embedded. All the benefits of analytic functionalism are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. are preserved. But there need be no commitment to the viability of an analytic/synthetic distinction. (Compare the diagnostician who can recognise a cancer  immediately and without inference  in the blur of an X-ray photograph.) But it can be claimed that the concepts employed in such capacities are also partly characterised by their p

Moreover, once someone possesses a recognitional concept, there can be nothing to stop them prising it apart from its surrounding beliefs and theories, t

Moreover, once someone possesses a recognitional concept, there can be nothing to stop them prising it apart from its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Moreover, once someone possesses a recognitional concept, there can be nothing to stop them prising it apart from its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Moreover, once someone possesses a recognitional concept, there can be nothing to stop them prising it apart from its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. om its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. m its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different 
 its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different c
its surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different co
ts surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different con
s surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different cons
 surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different const
surrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different constr
urrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different constru
rrounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construa
rounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construal
ounding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals
unding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals 
nding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals o
ding beliefs and theories, to form a concept which is barely recognitional. Our hypothesis can be that this is what takes place when people say that it is conceptually possible that there should be pains with quite different causal roles. While some or other version of theory-theory is now the dominant position in the philosophy of mind, this is not to say that there are no difficulties, and no dissenting voices. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals of

This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals of the extent of our folk psychological commitments, contrasting realist with instrumentalist accounts, and considering whether it is possible that our folk psychology might  as a substantive theory of the inner causes of behaviour  turn out to be a radically false theory, ripe for elimination. This is where we begin in chapter 2: we shall be considering different construals of the extent of our folk psychological commitments, contrasting realist with instrumentalist accounts, and considering whether it is possible that our folk psychology might  as a substantive theory of the inner causes of behaviour  turn out to be a radically false theory, ripe for elimination. And in chapters 7 and 9 we consider the challenges posed for any naturalistic account of the mental (and for theory-theory in particular) by the intentionality (or aboutness) of our menta

And in chapters 7 and 9 we consider the challenges posed for any naturalistic account of the mental (and for theory-theory in particular) by the intentionality (or aboutness) of our mental states, and by the phenomenal properties (or feel) of our experiences. eory-theory, the so-called simulationist account of our folk-psychological abilities. In fact one of the main messages of this book is that the theory-theory account of our common-sense psychology is a fruitful framework for considering the relations between folk and scientific psychologies, and so is to

In fact one of the main messages of this book is that the theory-theory account of our common-sense psychology is a fruitful framework for considering the relations between folk and scientific psychologies, and so is to that extent, at least, a progressive research programme (in the sense of Lak
uralistic account of the mental (and for theory-theory in particular) by the intentionality (or aboutness) of our mental states, and by the phenomenal properties (or feel) of our experiences.
